name: Santorini (Thera) — Minoan eruption
notes: Radiocarbon HPD window ~1627–1600 BCE; exact day unknown.

name: Vesuvius 79 CE — candidate Aug 24 (Julian)
notes: Traditional date from Pliny; time not fixed.
sources: GVP Vesuvius ; Pliny letters ; Oct-date debate

name: Samalas (Rinjani) 1257
notes: Identified as source of the 1257 sulfate peak; exact day unknown.
sources: Lavigne et al. 2013 (Nat. Geosci.) ; GVP Rinjani/Samalas

name: Tambora 1815 (climactic)
notes: 'Year Without a Summer' 1816; precise UT differs by source.

name: Laki (Skaftár Fires) start
notes: Severe SO2 release; 'dry fog' documented across Europe.

name: Huaynaputina 1600
notes: Large Plinian eruption; strong NH cooling signals.

name: Changbaishan / Paektu (Millennium eruption)
sources: Oppenheimer et al. 2017 ; Yang et al. 2021 ; GVP Changbaishan

name: Eldgjá fissure eruption
notes: Ice cores + chronicles: spring 939 through autumn 940.
sources: Nature 2018 (Eldgjá dating) ; Sigl et al. 2015 ; Volcanica 2025 review

name: Okmok II (Aleutians)
notes: PNAS 2020 assigns early 43 BCE; exact day unknown.
sources: McConnell et al. 2020 (PNAS) ; AVO Okmok summary

name: Hekla 1104 (historical)
notes: Traditional dating places eruption in autumn 1104; exact day unknown.
sources: Catalogue of Icelandic Volcanoes (HEK) ; GVP Hekla

name: Ilopango (TBJ) ~431 CE
notes: PNAS 2020 and follow-ups narrow to ~431 CE; broad window kept here.
sources: PNAS 2020 Smith et al. ; GVP Ilopango

name: Krakatoa 1883 (climax day)
notes: Climactic explosions; often-cited 10:02 local time not converted to UT here.

name: Hunga Tonga–Hunga Ha'apai 2022
notes: Largest atmospheric explosion recorded by modern instruments.
sources: Science 2022 (Proud et al.) ; NOAA NCEI 2024 ; GVP Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai
